TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit ActionBar extends Java.Lang.Object

Docs.summary: A primary toolbar within the activity that may display the activity title, application-level navigation affordances, and other interactive items.

remarks.para:
A primary toolbar within the activity that may display the activity title, application-level navigation affordances, and other interactive items.
Developer Guides

Beginning with Android 3.0 (API level 11), the action bar appears at the top of an activity's window when the activity uses the system's theme (or one of its descendant themes), which is the default. You may otherwise add the action bar by calling or by declaring it in a custom theme with the property.

Beginning with Android L (API level 21), the action bar may be represented by any Toolbar widget within the application layout. The application may signal to the Activity which Toolbar should be treated as the Activity's action bar. Activities that use this feature should use one of the supplied .NoActionBar themes, set the attribute to false or otherwise not request the window feature.

By adjusting the window features requested by the theme and the layouts used for an Activity's content view, an app can use the standard system action bar on older platform releases and the newer inline toolbars on newer platform releases. The ActionBar object obtained from the Activity can be used to control either configuration transparently.

When using the Holo themes the action bar shows the application icon on the left, followed by the activity title. If your activity has an options menu, you can make select items accessible directly from the action bar as "action items". You can also modify various characteristics of the action bar or remove it completely.

When using the Material themes (default in API 21 or newer) the navigation button (formerly "Home") takes over the space previously occupied by the application icon. Apps wishing to express a stronger branding should use their brand colors heavily in the action bar and other application chrome or use a in place of their standard title text.
From your activity, you can retrieve an instance of by calling .

In some cases, the action bar may be overlayed by another bar that enables contextual actions, using an . For example, when the user selects one or more items in your activity, you can enable an action mode that offers actions specific to the selected items, with a UI that temporarily replaces the action bar. Although the UI may occupy the same space, the APIs are distinct and independent from those for .
For information about how to use the action bar, including how to add action items, navigation modes and more, read the Action Bar developer guide.

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract Android.Views.View CustomView { get; set; }

remarks.para:
Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Set the action bar into custom navigation mode, supplying a view for custom navigation.
Custom navigation views appear between the application icon and any action buttons and may use any space available there. Common use cases for custom navigation views might include an auto-suggesting address bar for a browser or other navigation mechanisms that do not translate well to provided navigation modes.

Docs.summary: Get the Z-axis elevation of the action bar in pixels.

remarks.para:
Get method documentation [Android Documentation]
Get the Z-axis elevation of the action bar in pixels.
The action bar's elevation is the distance it is placed from its parent surface. Higher values are closer to the user.

Set the Z-axis elevation of the action bar in pixels.
The action bar's elevation is the distance it is placed from its parent surface. Higher values are closer to the user.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Hide() cil managed

Docs.summary: Hide the ActionBar if it is currently showing.

remarks.para: Hide the ActionBar if it is currently showing. If the window hosting the ActionBar does not have the feature it will resize application content to fit the new space available.

Instead of calling this function directly, you can also cause an ActionBar using the overlay feature to hide through . Hiding the ActionBar through this system UI flag allows you to more seamlessly hide it in conjunction with other screen decorations.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual int HideOffset { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Return the current vertical offset of the action bar.

remarks.para:
Get method documentation [Android Documentation]
Return the current vertical offset of the action bar.

The action bar's current hide offset is the distance that the action bar is currently scrolled offscreen in pixels. The valid range is 0 (fully visible) to the action bar's current measured (fully invisible).

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Set the current hide offset of the action bar.

The action bar's current hide offset is the distance that the action bar is currently scrolled offscreen in pixels. The valid range is 0 (fully visible) to the action bar's current measured (fully invisible).

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Enable hiding the action bar on content scroll.
If enabled, the action bar will scroll out of sight along with a view's content. The action bar must be in to enable hiding on content scroll.
When partially scrolled off screen the action bar is considered . A call to will cause it to return to full view.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(bool showHomeAsUp) cil managed

Docs.param: true to show the user that selecting home will return one level up rather than to the top level of the app.
Docs.summary: Set whether home should be displayed as an "up" affordance.

remarks.para: Set whether home should be displayed as an "up" affordance. Set this to true if selecting "home" returns up by a single level in your UI rather than back to the top level or front page.
To set several display options at once, see the setDisplayOptions methods.

Docs.param: A combination of the bits defined by the DISPLAY_ constants defined in ActionBar.
A bit mask declaring which display options should be changed.
Docs.summary: Set selected display options.

remarks.para: Set selected display options. Only the options specified by mask will be changed. To change all display option bits at once, see .
Example: setDisplayOptions(0, DISPLAY_SHOW_HOME) will disable the option. setDisplayOptions(DISPLAY_SHOW_HOME, DISPLAY_SHOW_HOME | DISPLAY_USE_LOGO) will enable and disable .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetHomeActionContentDescription(class Java.Lang.ICharSequence description) cil managed

Docs.param: New description for the Home action when enabled
Docs.summary: Set an alternate description for the Home/Up action, when enabled.

remarks.para: Set an alternate description for the Home/Up action, when enabled.

This description is commonly used for accessibility/screen readers when the Home action is enabled. (See .) Examples of this are, "Navigate Home" or "Navigate Up" depending on the display option. If you have changed the home-as-up indicator using to indicate more specific functionality such as a sliding drawer, you should also set this to accurately describe the action.
Setting this to null will use the system default description.

This description is commonly used for accessibility/screen readers when the Home action is enabled. (See .) Examples of this are, "Navigate Home" or "Navigate Up" depending on the display option. If you have changed the home-as-up indicator using to indicate more specific functionality such as a sliding drawer, you should also set this to accurately describe the action.
Setting this to 0 will use the system default description.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetHomeAsUpIndicator(class Android.Graphics.Drawables.Drawable indicator) cil managed

Docs.param: A drawable to use for the up indicator, or null to use the theme's default
Docs.summary: Set an alternate drawable to display next to the icon/logo/title when is enabled.

remarks.para: Set an alternate drawable to display next to the icon/logo/title when is enabled. This can be useful if you are using this mode to display an alternate selection for up navigation, such as a sliding drawer.
If you pass null to this method, the default drawable from the theme will be used.
If you implement alternate or intermediate behavior around Up, you should also call to provide a correct description of the action for accessibility support.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetHomeAsUpIndicator(int32 resId) cil managed

Docs.param: Resource ID of a drawable to use for the up indicator, or null to use the theme's default
Docs.summary: Set an alternate drawable to display next to the icon/logo/title when is enabled.

If you pass 0 to this method, the default drawable from the theme will be used.
If you implement alternate or intermediate behavior around Up, you should also call to provide a correct description of the action for accessibility support.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetHomeButtonEnabled(bool enabled) cil managed

Docs.param: true to enable the home button, false to disable the home button.
Docs.summary: Enable or disable the "home" button in the corner of the action bar.

remarks.para: Enable or disable the "home" button in the corner of the action bar. (Note that this is the application home/up affordance on the action bar, not the systemwide home button.)
This defaults to true for packages targeting < API 14. For packages targeting API 14 or greater, the application should call this method to enable interaction with the home/up affordance.
Setting the display option will automatically enable the home button.

remarks.para:
Set the icon to display in the 'home' section of the action bar. The action bar will use an icon specified by its style or the activity icon by default.
Whether the home section shows an icon or logo is controlled by the display option .

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetListNavigationCallbacks(class Android.Widget.ISpinnerAdapter adapter, class Android.App.ActionBar/IOnNavigationListener callback) cil managed

Docs.param: An adapter that will provide views both to display the current navigation selection and populate views within the dropdown navigation menu.
An OnNavigationListener that will receive events when the user selects a navigation item.
Docs.summary: Set the adapter and navigation callback for list navigation mode.

remarks.para:
Set the adapter and navigation callback for list navigation mode.
The supplied adapter will provide views for the expanded list as well as the currently selected item. (These may be displayed differently.)
The supplied OnNavigationListener will alert the application when the user changes the current list selection.

Docs.summary: Returns the number of tabs currently registered with the action bar.

Docs.summary: Returns a with an appropriate theme for creating views that will appear in the action bar.

remarks.para: Returns a with an appropriate theme for creating views that will appear in the action bar. If you are inflating or instantiating custom views that will appear in an action bar, you should use the Context returned by this method. (This includes adapters used for list navigation mode.) This will ensure that views contrast properly against the action bar.

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which contains the java.lang.Class JNI value corresponding to this type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control which jclass is provided to methods like .

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.
